Did a Monte Carlo for the optimistic scenario where cases drop in line with their historic best cases (8/9/2020 to 11/6/2020 and 3/24/2021 to 4/28/2021), linked here (https://github.com/gjusticea/forecast-tools/blob/master/Brazil%20Monte%20Carlo.R). Even with that as the best case it's below 19M in only 8% of cases, and I'd put a sudden decline at 50/50 at best, so 96% based on that. I'd adjust to 97% to account for the fact that there's a few sharp drops over holiday weekends that can get included in the projection without necessarily including their corresponding jump about a week later as delayed tests get done.  I do adjust back down though, I think there is some chance of a sustained drop, we are at a higher level than the history I'm using so there is more room for it to fall. In that vein, I may also be wrong about using raw instead of percentage changes. The Monte Carlo using percentage changes gives <19M  in the best case scenario a probability of 31%, so then my prediction would thus be ~87%, so I adjust down a bit for that too. Brazil needs to average <39k cases per day to make it below 19M and they're currently around 60k, so its unlikely especially given their history, but not impossible quite yet.

Confirmed that @Ryan-Beck has the numbers correct. We need below 23,734 to stay below 17.5M and daily average of 44,901 will get us to 19.0M cases in the next 71 days. To add some perspective, I ran the two-week average all the way back to December 2020. The last time Brazil had under 44,901 14-day average new cases was back on 1/12/21. That means that we've had sustained levels above the required daily rate for over 4 months with 2.33 months left. Also worth keeping in mind that the AVERAGE of the next 71 days has to be below 44,901 which means they'd not only need to reverse course, but do so to an extent that offsets any days that were above this average. Current 14-day average is 62,990 and 7-day is 64,665 so we are over 40% above required threshold and that is quickly eating into any hope that the average can be below 44,901. As sad as it is to say, it seems like Brazil has made a choice at this point and I think the only way they'd be able to do anything about their numbers would be drastic intervention. The likelihood of that is quite low, but there is still a chance they can keep things below 19.0M. FORECAST - When I look at this in another 3 weeks, I hope we will be somewhere around 16.8M cases and that will put us at needing 13,726 cases to hit 17.5M and 43,137 to hit 19.0M. Deviations from this should be considered when making my prediction at that time. The true expectation is above that because it only takes 47,045 cases per day to get to my 16.8M number. If current numbers hold steady, with a slight discount because we may be at a peak, we are expecting closer to 17.03M cases which leads to needing only 39,215 average for the remaining 50 days in order to see 19.0M.

15.7 Million + average of 60,000 cases per day for 72 days = 15.7 Million + 4.32 Million = 20.02 Million (using current average).
50,000 cases per day = 15.7 Million + 50,000 * 72 = 15.7 Million + 3.6 Million = 19.3 Million (using more realistic average).
40,000 cases per day = 15.7 Million + 40,000 * 72 = 15.7 Million + 2.88 Million = 18.58 Million (using somewhat optimistic average). Vaccinations are underway, with the possibility of a new contract with Pfizer, complemented by some CoronaVac vaccines manufactured by Butantan and another set from AstraZeneca, 46M and 26.5M respectively. However, the first large shipment from Pfizer won't arrive until September 2021. A rough estimate leaves only 10 million vaccines for Brazil between now and September [https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazil-looks-new-pfizer-contract-speed-up-vaccinations-2021-05-03/]. The greatest predictor of COVID-19 transmission appears to be seasonality, and in Brazil, winter is from June to September. Temperatures don't vary as much between seasons in Brazil, but the winter season in Brazil has been likened to Florida's, which did appear to exhibit COVID-19 seasonality-transmission patterns. I would have expected the rate of new cases to drop between now and July based on the impact of vaccinations and the patterns seen elsewhere, but Brazil will only be able to vaccinate another 10 million people between now and July, and winter is coming in June, so I think a realistic scenario is that new cases per day hover at 50K, giving an estimate of 19.3 Million confirmed cases in Brazil as of July 31 2021.

Cases have been declining since late March. It had not been clear to me whether this represented a temporary dip on a continued way up or a more substantial decline. It's now going on long enough that it seems to me that the current decline is likely not just "noise" on the way up. However, I still firmly believe that Brazil will see >19.0M cases by July 31 because the peak respiratory virus season is approximately from now through the end of July, there is no concerted national effort to stem transmission, and vaccination is proceeding slowly and primarily with a vaccine that has been found to be 50% effective at preventing cases in Brazil. It is as inconceivable to me that there will not be a winter peak in cases of a respiratory virus in Brazil as it was that the US would not see an increase in cases last fall and winter. Spreading in fall, winter and spring is what respiratory viruses do. Even if cases continue to decline a bit more, I am confident that they will be heading back up within the forecast period. There are 4.22M cases to go to reach 19.0M, and 89 days remaining in the forecast period; it will take an average of 47.4k cases/day to reach 19M, and Brazil is currently at a 7-day average of 58.6k cases/day. Ok, I'm trying hard to force myself to strategize about the Brier score. I'm updating from a previous forecast of 100% for >19.0M, not because I currently think there's actually any chance it'll be under 19.0M, but because I recognize that I could be wrong and that the Brier score will penalize me much more harshly for a 100% forecast than for a lower forecast if I am wrong. Cases in Brazil have recently declined a bit from their recent peak, but I still view this dip as likely to be "noise" on a path further up. If not, then perhaps something close to a plateau. Given that Bolsonaro is in power (so there's no national strategy of mitigation), winter hasn't even started there yet (although that will surely have a smaller effect near the Equator), and vaccination is proceeding slowly, I don't see how 19.0M will not be reached in the forecast period. 91 days left in the forecast period; 46.9k/day average to reach 19.0M; the current 7-day average is 59.7k/day.

My approach was to take about 20 countries which have similar GDP, and for all 20 look at % development in total cases across last 3 months.
All countries will be at different stages of second wave, third wave, etc. so hopefully a good range of outcomes. None have significant vaccinations programs.
Of 20 countries, 19 had increased total cases by > 50% in last 3 months. I've therefore assessed Brazil >19m total cases (a 30% increase on current), to have a approx. 95% chance.
Not near herd immunity. Using Sinovac which has a lower effectiveness. Community transmission still active.

Returning to update numbers as Brazil cases are now in a downtrend versus a month ago. Total cases required to hit 17.5M are 3,058,437 and 19M are 4,558,437. We have 93 days of reporting remaining before the numbers are finalized. As of today, the daily case rates required for 17.5M and 19M are 32,886 and 49,015 respectively. These requirements are down from 40,368 and 52,563 cases per day as of March 30 because Brazil had sustained high daily numbers throughout April. The last time Brazil's 7-day average was below 49,015 was 2/25/21 and the last time it was below 32,886 was before December of last year. So below 17.5M is a real long shot. Checking past 93 days of infections shows 5.596M total new cases and the lowest 7-day average has been is 44,267 on 2/16/21. If the back half of this surge looks like the front half in terms of speed and "normal" case rate levels for Brazil, then I'm expecting around 4.3M total cases in the remaining time frame. Current factors to consider are vaccination/immunization rates of the population. This will change both the potentially infected and the carrier numbers - as fewer people carry high viral loads and more peoples immune systems handle minor infections we will probably see fewer positive tests. People who have already had it are also less likely to get tested again. If new variants emerge that can re-infect already infected persons, then that has a potential to cause another spike in cases. This would increase the chances that we see the 4.5M cases required to hit 19M. Doubtful that COVID can continue to mutate so quickly that it continues to evade immune systems that have seen other variants already. Not an immunologist, but if your body has fought 2-3 strains of the disease there are definitely fewer mutations that could get past you and require you to get tested. I'm thinking the "normal" rate for infections is somewhere around 30,000 daily. Predict we will see Brazil approach this limit again and likely rebound upward as people begin to feel more comfortable living their lives normally. I'm leaning toward a 90% confidence window of 18.5M cases to about 19.4M cases right now which leaves me thinking there's slightly better chance we wind up on the south side of 19M.

(Quick note for anyone using Our World in Data data for this, WHO and OWID data are off by two days. So data OWID says is for April 10 is reported as April 12 in WHO data).  The threshold for below 19M as of today is an average of 50,623 cases per day, and they're way over that as is. The fastest paced drop in cases historically for Brazil was about -10k over about 3 weeks earlier this year, or -450 per day . If they averaged that pace of decline for every day until July 31 they'd be barely below the threshold, and that's if they started dropping at that pace immediately. Below 19M would require a swift and consistent decline that's not in keeping with Brazil's track record (i.e. everything is bad).  Below 19M is unlikely but not out of the question. The weekly peaks in positive tests do appear to have plateaued at least, and a couple of holidays coming up (Mother's Day and Corpus Christi) may lead to sudden dents in the trend as people fail to get tested. The decline rate is also an average, so as long as the trend is downward that'd still be fine. It's also possible that the sharp rise in ICU cases among young people will scare the young people who likely do a lot of the spreading into being more careful. There's a lot of time left, but Brazil's track record is poor, and below 19M would require something pretty far outside the ordinary as far as Brazil and COVID are concerned.

0. Initial: 
~1.1M / month considering 13M cases since Apr 3 2020 would yield abt 17M cases by end of July. Restraining to Oct 3 yields about 1.3M/mo, and already considers a post-restrictions period in october (8M cases / 6mo). Initial guess be something in 17.4 - 18.3M. Considering the ratio observed in the past 3 months, yield an upper limit of 20. [1] 1. Restrictions:
State governments have rolled out multiple restrictions over the past month or so. The impact of these has been questionable in Brazil (as the possible answers indicate). My prior for these is that circulation and commerce restrictions tend to drive new case numbers down a few weeks after the start of restrictions.
Taking the reduction in September (25%), October (50%) as best case scenarios for 1, 2 months after restrictions, we could go from ~70k daily cases to 52-35k cases/day. The "isolation indices" published by Sao Paulo [2] support a similar level of isolation in March 2021 compared to August 2020. Sao Paulo seems to be an OK proxy for self-isolation in most other states [3]. After these initial successes, restrictions will most likely be lifted (as happened in all states last year). This could mean that cases creep up again the following month, or maybe vaccines play a significant enough role in reducing contagion. 1.i) Jan - Mar as guess for April 2021
Worst-case initial guesses (1.75M / month, ~58k daily cases) could be updated to 44-29k cases in the coming months of May, June. We could take this to mean daily increases of 58k, 44k, 29k in April, May, June. I'll defer analysing the vaccine impact and place July between 20 (1/3 reduction) and 44k daily cases.
This takes us to 4.65M - 5.425M new cases in the coming months => 17.65 - 18.425M. 1.ii) March 2021 as the ratio for April 2021
Starting from March 2021 as the guess for april leads to a significantly worse outcome: (~65k, 49, 32.5, 22-49) => 5.22 - 6.06 => 18.22M - 19.06M 2. Temporary wrap-up
I'll temporarily settle for the middle ground between (1.i), (1.ii), with a bit more weight (2:1) towards (1.i), as March of 2021 was an extreme month, most likely due to Carnival etc. This yields 17.84 - 18.63, which falls entirely  in the 3rd option. I'll remove some of that certainty by considering that I was pretty generous in the atenuation effect of restriction measures. Also, vaccination (or highiers compliance to isolation) could drive new case rates down faster. Going with (0, 5, 60, 35). I think modeling different case trajectories here is very helpful, and comparing different paths to the breakpoints of the question, and seeing what looks reasonable. 14.5M cases: average of 19k cases per day henceforth
16M cases: average of 31k cases per day henceforth
17.5M cases: average of 42k cases per day henceforth
19M cases: average of 53k cases per day henceforth Most paths using a simply upside down parabola with a peak at 80,000-90,000 somewhere in mid-April put you well over the 53k average necessary to hit 19M. The most reasonable path to get below is non-parabolic, with a peak around 80,000 in the next couple weeks, and a sharp fall to 20,000-30,000 per day by late June after which the sharp fall slows. That optimistic path (arbitrarily calculated fitting a polynomial line to some points in Excel) puts you at 46k per day average.  Picking a path relies on the details of Brazil’s COVID efforts. Brazil's track record is... poor for COVID, and going by Bolsonaro's recent speech it doesn't look like there will be centralized effort to change that any time soon. They're yet to start manufacturing the AstraZeneca vaccine as they'd planned and are instead importing the SinoVac one. Unfortunately the overall poor response hasn't gone on long enough to get them close to herd immunity, their cases are about 6% of the population so far, and that's roughly consistent in the states of Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo. Even with a markup for undiagnosed cases of like 5x that's still not close. That’s also not to mention the new variant that’s arisen in Brazil, which is most likely more contagious than the older one.  The vaccine rollout will be interesting, since it seems they plan to rely on SinoVac and AstraZeneca. SinoVac only had 50% efficacy in preventing COVID in Brazilian trials, but 78% efficacy against "mild-severe" cases. Even if it doesn't prevent many COVID infections and or spread, widespread vaccination will likely decrease reported cases by preventing symptomatic ones that lead to testing.  It’s difficult to isolate the effect of vaccines on cases though in other countries. Other countries have been able to achieve sharp drops concurrent with vaccine distribution, such as the US and UK, however, the UK did it while reaching ~40% of the population with at least one vaccine dose as of today, and the US ~26%, on top of lockdown measures after winter spikes in both cases, as well as warmer weather that likely led to people spending less time indoors.  On the other hand, France and Italy have been rolling out vaccines as well but cases have been slowly rising for months, and their large spike was before the winter. Both Italy and France’s vaccine rollouts have been somewhat slower, reaching about 10% of the population with one dose by now. Canada had the same winter spike as the US, but its vaccine rollout has been much slower, getting to <10% of the population. It still had the sharp drop after the winter despite lack of vaccination, but cases have been going up recently while the US has been flat or declining. The cases of Canada vs the US and France/Italy vs the UK makes me question how good of a model I really have for predicting the effects of different country-specific factors on cases. I think it’s safe to say that vaccines aren’t really a significant factor in case counts (they are in death counts though) until they reach huge chunks of the population, like maybe 20% or more, and even then, it’s still not clear. Brazil has only reached about 6%, so even if they are able to ramp up in the coming months they’ve got a lot of ground to cover.  Overall, it’s possible for Brazil to get below 19M if their new cases peak in the next couple weeks and fall quickly from there. Whether that’ll happen is the big question. The negative argument is that they probably don’t have vaccines working in their favor yet, cases are still trending up and COVID trends take a while to change direction, and the federal administration doesn’t seem like it has much intention of improving its response. On the other hand, some governors are stepping up to get vaccines and push for lockdowns, but most importantly to me, the model that I have of explaining country-by-country results using vaccines and lockdowns and weather doesn’t yield very good predictions for the countries I mentioned before. Absent good explanations of how countries fare with COVID, I lean on Brazil’s track record, which is unequivocally bad. In the GJP2.0 pessimism around Brazil was heavily rewarded. Maybe it’ll be mostly due to variants, maybe lack of government response, maybe something else, maybe a mix, but if the past is any indication, it won’t look good.

Update.
I wish I could include a picture here: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/brazil#what-is-the-cumulative-number-of-confirmed-cases
Plot from Nov. 5, 2020 to the present, then click on the "LOG" button in the upper left of the graph. It's about as perfect a line as you can get, showing exponential growth. Of course, past exponential growth doesn't mean exponential growth will continue, but I don't see much to slow it down substantially in the near term.
Even if growth is linear, at 2M cases/month, Brazil will get to over 19.0 million by July 31. And growth is exponential, not linear, heading into fall and winter. Update 5/1: Forecast still holding. With exponential growth, noise also grows in amplitude. In other words, the ups and downs in cases/day get bigger, too. I see the recent trend downwards as in the noise, i.e., just bumps along the way up; indeed, cases are going back up again. 14.66M cases as of 4/30. 4.34M to go to 19M, or 47.2k/day. 68k cases today; 60.3k/day 7-day average and climbing. If cases/day remained flat at 60k for all of May (and I think they'll go up), then by the end of May, there will be 2.48M cases left to go to reach 19M, or 40.7k/day.  Some think vaccination will make a big difference. I agree it will make some difference. But if they give ~1M doses/day, there will still be an awful lot of susceptible people around by the end of July. As of today, only 6.3% of the country is fully vaccinated; 13.6% has had at least one dose. In all of April, they added only 4.2% of the population (8.9M) to the fully vaccinated category. If they give 1M doses/day, then by July 31, 13.6% + (~2/3 * 93 days * 1M doses/day) / 211M people *100% = 13.6% + 29.4% = 43% will be fully vaccinated, still below the herd immunity threshold even if you say that half of the nonvaccinated remainder of the population is already immune because they will have been infected with SARSCoV2. But honestly, will that many people be vaccinated by then? We're hitting vaccine hesitancy in the US at 30% of the population having received at least one dose. On the other hand, cases are declining here in the US because of a combination of seasonality, vaccination and natural immunity, and behavior, and so people aren't worrying as much. All in all, of course, the more people you remove from the susceptible pool by vaccination, the less the virus can spread, but I don't expect vaccination to make that big of a dent on *infections* for a while. Also, with July in the Southern Hemisphere being equivalent to January in the Northern Hemisphere in terms of seasonality, Brazil still has a long way to go with fall and winter case growth; cases/day grew throughout the fall and early winter until they peaked in the US in early January. Seasonality is weaker in Brazil, but nonetheless, I can't help but think we'll see at least a somewhat similar pattern in Brazil. In short, with Bolsonaro (i.e., no federal leadership favoring containment policies) + winter + slow vaccination, I don't see how cases can be under 19M by the end of July. I think cases should definitely be on the wane by sometime in July and perhaps slightly earlier, if Brazil can ramp up vaccination, but I don't think we're going to see 7-day average case numbers in the 40k's for a while.
